See https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/sdbusplus/+/74359.

You can run the above commit against your schema as follows:

```
$ tools/sdbus++ -r ../phosphor-dbus-interfaces/yaml event exception-header xyz.openbmc_project.Sensor.Threshold
```

Your current code at least fails as follows:

```
jsonschema.exceptions.ValidationError: 'errno' is a required property
```
I suspect you have an old revision of sdbusplus in a docker container?
I'm not sure there is a hard requirement that we make these match the Redfish name.  Up to you if you want them to.

Cool. But everything so far has been on par. One reason why I would not stick to the redfish defined names would be if the name does not match the coding style. But since its BlahBlahFirstCaseUp its fine I guess.
nit: convention will be for these to all be UPPER_SNAKE_CASE.
Validation fails. `jsonschema.exceptions.ValidationError: 'enum[Value.interface.Unit]' is not one of ['string', 'size', 'int64', 'uint64', 'double', 'object_path']`
This should be 1.0.0.  Even if Redfish has a different version, these are not intended to match.
Looks like I need to do something here to ensure that these are not in here.  I'm not expecting the Redfish version to be in here.
We would need some way to indicate/document which version of the registry this is conforming to.

They're suppose to be backwards compatible.  There isn't anything you should need to do here for it.

Maybe we'll learn that is wrong in the future, but I don't want to be updating these files every time Redfish makes a new release.

CI Failure:

```
    Running commit_gitlint
-: UC1 Line exceeds max length (111>72).
    It's possible you intended to use one of the following exceptions:
    1. Put logs or shell script in a quoted section with triple quotes (''')
        before and after the section
    2. Put a long link at the bottom in a footnote.
        example: [1] https://my_long_link.com
    Line that was too long:
: "https://lore.kernel.org/openbmc/SJ2PR15MB5801EA7FA684D3B21EE32CE3AB8D2@SJ2PR15MB5801.namprd15.prod.outlook.com/"
```
Rename this to ReadingAboveUpperWarningThreshold to match with OpenBMC limits.

Added SoftShutdown and made both HardShutdown and SoftShutdown map to the same redfish event. Patrick mentioned it should be fine for multiple events to map to the same redfish message. One way from the user side would be to use the threshold_value to know that we are dealing with different thresholds here.

Check if this is ok or if I should leave the redfish mapping out so it shows up as a custom OPENBMC threshold.
Added PerformanceLoss as well since that was missing as well.

I don't see en section https://grok.openbmc.org/xref/openbmc/docs/designs/event-logging.md?r=9a0248b5#503

@Patrick have you kept this section optional intentionally?

Yes.  I should update the design document.  The way I wrote the schema you can only have `redfish-mapping` OR `en:` section.  The `en` section is what will be used to generate the Redfish registry (for custom events not in the standard).
